posts.name: Addie Zimmerman
posts.cooked:
Assume that, hypothetically, someone on your team doesn‚Äôt know anything about electrical, but wants to learn. Unfortunately, they find the subject a bit daunting and don‚Äôt really know where to start. Do any of you have any good tips, resources, or anything of the like that someone (not me) can use to get well-versed in electrical before the season starts? Any help is greatly appreciated!

I‚Äôm‚Ä¶ asking for a friend.

posts.name: Marc Antinossi
posts.cooked:
The documentation in the WPI library helped me build a good foundation to my still limited electrical knowledge:

The goal of this document is to provide a brief overview of the hardware components that make up the FRC ¬Æ Control System. Each component will contain a brief description of the component function ...

Overview: Detailed diagram of all of the components and how they are connected. Diagram courtesy of FRC ¬Æ Team 3161 and Stefen Acepcion. Gather Materials: Locate the following control system compon...

Between these two links, one should be able to fairly quickly design a controls system and wire their robot.

posts.name: Mansour Mohamed
posts.cooked: CD is honestly a great resource cause it allows you to see different issues teams have had and how they solved it. For learning just barebones FRC electrical there‚Äôs FRC Zero , Spectrum‚Äôs training resources , and Citrus‚Äôs training resources . Those are the best things to learn what you need just to be a bel to wire a robot as well as fix problems that may arise.

posts.name: Anika
posts.cooked: These were very helpful and taught me most of what I needed to know. If you have access to a robot, wiring a CAN loop really helped me learn where all of the components were and was a relatively easy way to get a basis for electrical.

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked:
These are 2491‚Äôs electrical docs. Make sure to check all the tabs.

Achieving Wiring Credentials	3 From 0 To Competition Ready Robot	4 Basic Skills, and Best Practices	5 Crimping	6 Labeling	6 Using Regular Label Maker	6 Using The Heat Shrink Label Maker	7 Wire Management	7 Routing & Bundling	7 Zip Ties	10...

posts.name: David Swed
posts.cooked:
In my opinion, the most important part of doing electrical is just making sure it doesn‚Äôt break during a match. Made a presentation last year on the most common failures and how to prevent them: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1DtPFvJv64e6FymtbhhrVlMp6roh0l_S5xkROfEUnYfg/edit?usp=drivesdk

TLDR: ‚Ä¢ Secure your batteries with a metal frame in all dimensions ‚Ä¢ Make sure your team has a battery beak and knows how to test batteries before every match ‚Ä¢ Strain relief every single connection point, if you tug on a wire it should tug on a zip tie and not the actual connection ‚Ä¢ solder your CAN bus and put heat shrink on your connections. Trust me,just do it, it‚Äôs the worst thing to trouble shoot

link_counts.title: Top 7 Electrical Failures that kill your Match & how to prevent them - Google Slides

posts.cooked:
3414 focused heavily into guides for crimping as the most common failure point. However our own docs do include a lot of other more general things that should be checked out. We also link to  other resources we used and think would be helpful for others.

This Doc is private

link_counts.title: Hackbots Electrical Standard Practices Guide (Electrical Manual) 2024-25

posts.name: Brennan Macaig
posts.cooked:
Electrical in FRC is a challenging topic to discuss, especially since so much of it is opinion and knowledge based. The electrical work in FRC is also FRC specific, and the components in FRC are unlikely to be seen outside of the FRC environment (so unlike say, OnShape or Java, new students and mentors will have little to no experience with FRC electrical components beyond a wire).

For example, in this thread someone has recommended soldering your CAN wiring, while other resources linked in this thread recommend that you do not solder your CAN wires. It can be overwhelming to find a starting point with so many opinions that are contradictory to each other.

Personally, I find that it is best to start with an overview of ‚Äúwhat do you need to make a robot work‚Äù. Start by identifying components, and learning what they do and what they require to operate. I think this can either be achieved by reading some of the WPILib resources on how to wire, but also from reading the game manual (the game manual tells you with pictures what is absolutely required, and how to wire it!) After you have an understanding of what components do what, then I think you can start diving into more of the other resources and training around the FRC electrical system.

As with many things, I look to the persistent wisdom of @JamesCH95 for increasing reliability in what I call the critical power paths, specifically:

Battery terminals

Main breaker terminals

Battery negative and main breaker to PDH / PDP

PDH / PDP to roboRIO

PDH / PDP to robot radio, including any POE injector in this path

roboRIO to robot radio ethernet

A failure here means that your robot will stop connecting to FMS , which means that your robot has disconnected and may take anywhere from a few seconds (a loose ethernet cable) to a full minute (radio restart) to reconnect to the match.

Some other advice I have gathered throughout my time that I pass along to students on 6324 or teams that I work with as a CSA :

The first suspect for a significant and frequent brown out early in a match (robot RSL is ‚Äústuttering‚Äù) is a loose power wire on your battery or main breaker. Once again, James has a solution for you on the battery side.

Neat wiring doesn‚Äôt mean hiding all your wiring away. Wiring should be easy to visually diagnose. Ideally we should be able to without using any hands trace a wire from start to finish

It doesn‚Äôt matter what connector you pick (anderson, molexSL, wago levernut, etc.) for a specific task on your robot, just pick what works best for you and your team and standardize to it. They all have their own pros and cons, and are not fundamentally different enough to matter.

You can always remove more wire later. Start longer than you think you need, you will be surprised how much longer wire runs can be when you go around obstacles instead of over or through them. When in doubt, cut an inch or two longer.

posts.name: Owen Flanagan
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôm not electrical so I can‚Äôt tell you how to get good at electrical but I can tell you how to stop your programming team from getting angry at you.

Check your work whenever possible and as much as possible. If your working with CAN then make sure that rev client/tuner can see everything its supposed to on the can bus. After you‚Äôve wired a motor try and run it in its respective can tool(if possible) and make sure it behaves as expected. Check that sensors are responding how they are expected too. Tug on anything and everything you can and make sure that it holds firm. I know it sounds like a pain(and sometimes it is) but it will catch a ton of errors before they need to be solved later.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôll add some context to this one, as it‚Äôs a pain point we see some years. Often, the controls students can‚Äôt effectively help troubleshoot controls failures, as they simply don‚Äôt understand how the things they‚Äôre plugging in work, how they communicate, or their diagnostic tooling.

If you want to be a rockstar controls student, don‚Äôt stop learning at ‚ÄúGreen->Green + Yellow->Yellow‚Äù, but learn the diagnostic tools for your motor controller (Rev Hardware client, Phoenix Tuner, etc), and pay attention to what programming expects from sensors so mounting can account for it. Sometimes it‚Äôs knowing FOV on rangefinders to make sure nothing dangles in the way, or just checking that a switch triggers in the way they need it. Knowing the physical interfaces programming might need to access (such as motor controller USB ports) can also prevent errors later.

A good controls student will make sure they power on and blink, but a great student can make sure it‚Äôs actually usable and ready to go when the bot is handed over to the coders, and maintainable when something goes wrong later.

While this isn‚Äôt usually controls 101, if you‚Äôre a returning student, looking at it from this angle might help apply existing hardware knowledge. Just start looking at the ‚Äúgetting started guides‚Äù for those, and pay close attention to the parts talking about physical interfaces, plugs, and diagnostics/testing.

posts.name: Shoumik | 8866 | Driver
posts.cooked:
I love LYNK‚Äôs Library of Knowledge as a good library of resources from top teams like 1678 and 3847 for an introduction into the basics of FRC Electrical. Definitely helped with teaching new members the overall basics before diving into what we do specifically as a team (connectors, practices, etc).

I also think that the Unofficial FRC Discord is an underrated source of knowledge. I would attribute the electrical channel in the server as one of best resources that drastically increased my knowledge and the quality of our electrical. What I personally did was scroll through some messages to figure out who talked the most (Banks, Nick, Peter, and Daltz are a few people who come to mind) and then searched all the messages that person sent in the channel. I just read through a few hundred messages each day last summer, which really helped me get a better understanding, especially because the people that I listed talk a lot in that channel to help people, so you gain a lot of insight on how to diagnose common electrical issues. I‚Äôd also recommend asking questions in that channel (since one of those people I listed is a mentor for a team in PCH , I personally asked questions through the district-specific server, but the Unofficial Discord is great for asking questions in). You sometimes get ignored but just wait a bit and resend your question, though don‚Äôt repeatedly repost your message like every 5 minutes.

9496 LYNK‚Äôs site for housing knowledge and information for the team.

I can‚Äôt help you with electrical.

But I did just want to say that you shouldn‚Äôt self-deprecate because you do not know something. That doesn‚Äôt make you a dummy; if you were a dummy you would not have asked to learn more. It‚Äôs also okay to not know something and you don‚Äôt need to be afraid to admit it.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
A couple of valuable lessons from making electronics work in the oilfield, where the most favoritest tool is the sledgehammer

Connectors are your most common point of failure.  Eliminate them when you can!

Pressure washers can FILL sealed electrical boxes.  If you can imagine sticking a needle through the seal of something, you can blow water past it.  Force a 90 degree turn or two and your box suddenly stays dry!

Potting things in plain epoxy is a bad idea.  Pops big chips off the board and crushes capacitors.  Seal around big chips to keep the goop out, and mix micro-balloons into the epoxy.  Makes it cheaper too!

Hardware store silicone is BAD for electronics.  Full of acetic acid.  Buy electronic grade!

Acid plumbing flux (zinc chloride) is - hell - on electrical stuff. ONLY use it when you have to get solder to stick to stainless steel, nichrome wire, and other ‚Äúwhy the heck are you trying to solder that!!!‚Äù items.  And clean, clean, clean after you use it.  Keep it away from the kiddos‚Ä¶

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
@zimshady it appears that your team is in the Orlando FL area. After studying the resources many people have already provided, it would be good to get in touch with some of the established teams in your area to learn from them, in-person. A lot of building a reliable electrical control system depends on using good techniques. It is much easier to teach such techniques in-person. It would be best to choose teams that you have seen that have reliable control systems that don‚Äôt look like ‚Äúbowls of spaghetti‚Äù so you are less likely to learn good habits instead of bad habits.

It would be good to bring along a few other teammates who are also interested in working on the electrical system AND have demonstrated good attention to detail and are careful about their work. In over 12 years of mentoring teams (and many decades working in electronics manufacturing), I have not found a way to teach someone how to consistently be careful about their work and consistently pay attention to detail.
